etymologies: Middle English (denoting a spool for thread): shortening of Old French espole or from Middle Low German spōle, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch spoel and German Spule. The verb dates from the early 17th century

definitions: a cylindrical device on which film, magnetic tape, thread, or other flexible materials can be wound; a reel
shortDefinitions: cylindrical device on which film, magnetic tape, thread, or other flexible materials can be wound

definitions: a cylindrical device attached to a fishing rod and used for winding and unwinding the line as required.
shortDefinitions: cylindrical device attached to fishing rod

definitions: denoting furniture of a style popular in England in the 17th century and North America in the 19th century, typically ornamented with a series of small knobs resembling spools
shortDefinitions: denoting furniture of style popular in England in 17th century and North America in 19th century

definitions: wind (magnetic tape, thread, etc.) on to a spool

examples.text: he was trying to spool his tapes back into the cassettes with a pencil eraser

shortDefinitions: wind (magnetic tape, thread, etc.) on to spool

definitions: be wound on or off a spool

examples.text: the plastic reel allows the line to run free as it spools out

shortDefinitions: be wound on or off spool

definitions: send (data that is intended for printing or processing on a peripheral device) to an intermediate store
etymologies: acronym from simultaneous peripheral operation online

examples.text: users can set which folder they wish to spool files to

definitions: (of an engine) increase its speed of rotation, typically to that required for operation

examples.text: a jet engine can take up to six seconds to spool up

shortDefinitions: (of engine) increase its speed of rotation
